TopicTitle: Some interesting observations about the maneuver system and thrust during time warp

Articles.Content:
I ran some tests with with the maneuver node thrust during time warp, to see how the system works and whether it was quirks and limitations. Here's what I found, using a simple ion vessel

 

First here is what you see when you do a very slow burn (it's about a 50 min burn). Since my orbital period is still fairly fast as you can see a burn starting pro-grade will eventually crash me into the ground because it won't be pro-grade at some point anymore. 

The good thing is that the prediction is on spot - when I executed the burn I was pretty much on the predicted trajectory. 

An important limitation however is that I can't plan a burn where I keep my ship aligned pro-grade, which would lead to a spiraling out kind of plot. Though it is important to remember that I also could not execute that kind of burn in time-warp, since rotation is disabled. If I wanted to do a 50 minute staying pro-grade burn I'd have to do it in normal speed.  As I mentioned in other posts I think this limits the utility of burning in time-warp to insertion burns or to burns where you are in an orbit with a very long period (e.g. around Kerbol), as then your heading would not change relative to the prograde and other markers.

 

Now here is a more fun thing to do with time warp. My vessel looked like this:

It's bit hard to see, but I have two Dawn ion drives in a symmetrical configuration, but attached separately so I could easily control them individually. If I deactivated one of them and burned only with the other one my craft started to spin due to the off-center thrust, as expected.

However, if I start the engine and immediately engage time-warp rotations get disabled and thrust seems to work as if it in line with center of mass. Ergo, if you have an vessel with off-center thrust  (e.g. due to collision damage) it becomes perfectly usable if you do your burns during time warp. 

I don't know if this is a real issue - after all most of us don't build vessels with off-center thrust. What it does show in my opinion is that the ability to burn during time-warp is a pretty simple and naive implementation. I am not using naive in a deregatory sense, but referring to it not really giving much thought about how it interacts with the rest of the game and physics.

tldr; burning through time warps ignores assymetrical thrust configurations.
